Interpersonal and Communication Skills: Collaborative group work in research projects
Problem-Solving and Analytical Skills: Identifying research gaps in education literature

courseTitle: Design of Service Delivery Plans to Meet the Needs of Military Connected Children and Families
courseDescription: Students will apply their foundational and assessment knowledge for supporting military students to a capstone project in service delivery program design. This course will engage participants in surveying and considering a range of services, program elements, and strategies that may be employed to improve educational, social, and emotional school experiences for children of military-related families. Participants will engage in processes for selecting and preparing to implement optimal support strategies and structures to meet the identified needs of military students in their school setting. They will become familiar with and prepared to craft specific plans to utilize, for the benefit of military children, their peers and families: (a) various school, community, and government services; (b) classroom- and school-based programs designed to improve academic achievement and/or emotional well-being; and (c) classroom- and school-based strategies for designing and implementing programs and services that meet the needs of these children and their families.
Technical and Digital Skills: Utilization of school, community, and government services
Designing and implementing classroom- and school-based programs and services
Interpersonal and Communication Skills: Communication with military students and families
Problem-Solving and Analytical Skills: Critical evaluation of service delivery plans
Designing programs for academic achievement and emotional well-being
Organizational and Leadership Skills: Crafting specific plans for military children
Leading the design and implementation of support programs

courseDescription: In this course principal licensure candidates learn to identify organizational needs, develop research-based strategies to address those needs, and use data-driven planning to implement, monitor, and manage processes involved in implementing change strategies.
Cooperative Education.

The internship is designed to establish a bond between theory and practice, while providing opportunities for independent and guided practice, feedback, coaching, and reflection. Ultimately, it will engage prospective administrators in planned and coordinated active learning experiences. Pre- or

Each internship course will require students to complete a minimum of 160 hours in each course.  Course is designed to provide field experiences which will prepare them to serve as instructional and curriculum leadership in K-12 environments.  Student must produce 1) a portfolio with required artifacts; 2) prepare a 10-12 reflective paper according to identified guidelines and 3) complete internship evaluation with mentor and college supervisor at least three times during the term.

The student completes an in-depth study of a critical issue in his/her profession and documents the work in a critical issue paper.  Student must be able to demonstrate written and oral communication skills and critical and analytical skills in dealing with a major issue in educational leadership. Course to be taken near completion of program.
Problem-Solving and Analytical Skills: Analytical skills in dealing with major issues

courseDescription: The study of selected topics in educational leadership.  Arranged individually with students.
Problem-Solving and Analytical Skills: Critical thinking in educational leadership decision-making
Organizational and Leadership Skills: Effective leadership strategies in educational settings

courseTitle: Strategic Leadership and Management for School Improvement
courseDescription: This course is designed to give students entering the ODU Licensure program an understanding of the complex roles and challenges of a school principal, while focusing on the constantly changing nature of administrative responsibility.  Students develop an integrated view of the knowledge base, research and practice of administration within a context of multiple perspectives and a wide range of thinking. The purpose of the course is to increase understanding of education, the role of educational administration, the forces that are moving education into a new era, the transitions that are occurring, and the use of the latest, best practices to improve the education of all children.
Interpersonal and Communication Skills: Building strong relationships with staff and students
Problem-Solving and Analytical Skills: Analyzing educational data to identify areas for improvement
Developing strategic plans for school enhancement
Implementing solutions to address educational challenges
Organizational and Leadership Skills: Strategic planning for school improvement initiatives
Leading change management processes within educational settings
Developing and implementing a shared vision for school success

courseDescription: This course is an in-depth study of effective data based decision-making practices for contemporary school leaders.  Formative and summative data based decision making practices will be explored, as well as how to work with large and small groups of staff members to analyze multiple measures of data and create school improvement designs for student and school success.  An emphasis is placed on using data to make decisions at the division, school, and classroom levels.
Interpersonal and Communication Skills: Effective communication of data insights to stakeholders
Problem-Solving and Analytical Skills: Identifying trends and patterns in data
Developing actionable strategies based on data analysis
Evaluating the effectiveness of school improvement designs
Organizational and Leadership Skills: Building a culture of data-driven decision-making
Implementing data analysis frameworks for continuous improvement

courseDescription: This course teaches aspiring school leaders how politics and policy shapes school-based decision making and how school leaders can influence politics and policy processes to improve learning environments for children.  The course focuses contemporary problems that confront school leaders as they work to improve the conditions of learning for their students, faculty and staff.  To effectively address and solve problems school leaders need to understand the processes of policymaking at various educational levels and to develop the relevant skills of policymaking needed at the school level.  Thus, this course addresses the following three essential principles of educational politics and policy as they apply to school level administrators:  political and policy dynamics that influence their work in schools; accurately identify, diagnose, and develop the right solutions to the right problems in order to achieve instructional goals of the school and division; and confront, engage in, and effectively deal with conflict (i.e., politics) emanating from within the school, division, or community in order to achieve school and division learning goals.
Technical and Digital Skills: Utilizing educational technology for policy implementation
Problem-Solving and Analytical Skills: Root cause analysis of educational challenges
Organizational and Leadership Skills: Creating a shared vision among stakeholders

courseDescription: This course serves as an introduction for prospective administrators to the social and political context of the educational environment.  The underlying concept of this course is collaboration.  Today's administrators face a variety of multifaceted challenges in their daily routines.  Therefore, they must recongize the impact of political, socioeconomic situations, community diversity, equity issues, and school community relations on their leadership practices.
Technical and Digital Skills: Understanding of social and political context in educational environments
Impact assessment of political and socioeconomic situations on leadership practices
Problem-Solving and Analytical Skills: Critical evaluation of the impact of various factors on leadership practices
Organizational and Leadership Skills: Management of political and socioeconomic influences

courseDescription: This course exposes students to the essential elements of instructional leadership.  Central to the skills and knowledge necessary to be an effective instructional leader are a deep understanding of the learning sciences that inform us about the essence of effective teaching.  Effective instructional leaders have a solid basis for assessing and promoting high quality instruction, giving them the tools to proactively build a school's organizational capacity of sustained growth in student achievement.  Students will engage in reading, reflection, dialog, writing, problem solving and field-work, designed to build an understanding of how these topics are intrinsically tied to supporting teachers in their classrooms through facilitating better understandings of standards and accountability, effective lesson planning and curriculum development, assessment and grading, classroom management and discipline.
Organizational and Leadership Skills: Assessing and promoting high quality instruction
Building organizational capacity for student achievement

courseDescription: This course develops student's skills, knowledge and dispositions in the area of instructional leadership.  Students will explore how effective instructional leaders can use their integrated knowledge of quality instruction and the core principles of learning to set the mission and vision for the school, facilitate school improvement planning and professional development and finally how instructional supervision is used to integrate these activities and support the growth of individual teachers as well as building organizational capacity.  Effective instructional leaders have a solid basis for assessing and promoting high quality instruction, giving them the tools to proactively build a school's organizational capacity for sustained growth in student achievement.  Students will engage in reading, reflection, dialog, writing, problem solving and field-work, designed to help them build an integrated understanding of those leadership practices that help support teacher instructional growth and those that build organizational capacity for sustained improvement.
Organizational and Leadership Skills: Setting mission and vision for the school

courseDescription: This course examines how public schools are financed, including an analysis of the sources of revenues, the distribution of revenue, and the budgeting and expenditure of revenue.  Special emphasis will be placed on the Virginia funding formula, education as an investment in human capital, and how funding relates to student achievement.  Students will learn the fiscal management skills and understandings necessary to manage the finances of a school or school system, including the study of system and school procedures related to budget planning, budget management, internal school account management, inventory control, and purchasing procedures.
Interpersonal and Communication Skills: Collaboration with school administrators and staff
Problem-Solving and Analytical Skills: Student achievement impact assessment on funding
Organizational and Leadership Skills: Financial leadership in school or school system

courseDescription: This course is an introduction to law, particularly with respect to federal and state statutes and court decisions dealing with the public schools.  The topics span a wide spectrum of law-related concerns.  The study of law is intended to be practical by providing the legal understanding necessary for a school administrator to negotiate his or her way through the maze of difficult legal and ethical matters commonly faced each day.
Study of selected topics in educational leadership.
Problem-Solving and Analytical Skills: Problem identification and resolution in educational leadership
Organizational and Leadership Skills: Team building and motivation in educational settings

courseDescription: Topics in Educational Leadership.
Organizational and Leadership Skills: Implementing change management initiatives in educational institutions

Students develop an integrated view of the knowledge base, research and practice of administration within a context of multiple perspectives and a wide range of thinking. The purpose of the course is to increase understanding of education, the role of educational administration, the forces that are moving education into a new era, the transitions that are occurring, and the use of the latest, best practices to improve the education of all children.
Technical and Digital Skills: Utilizing digital communication platforms for school administration
Interpersonal and Communication Skills: Effective communication with stakeholders (parents, teachers, students)
Building strong relationships with staff and community members
Problem-Solving and Analytical Skills: Analyzing educational data to identify areas for improvement
Developing strategies to address challenges in school improvement
Implementing evidence-based practices for educational reform
Organizational and Leadership Skills: Strategic planning for school improvement initiatives
Team building and collaboration within educational institutions
Implementing change management processes in school administration

Formative and summative data based decision making practices will be explored, as well as how to work with large and small groups of staff members to analyze multiple measures of data and create school improvement designs for student and school success.  An emphasis is placed on using data to make decisions at the division, school, and classroom levels.
Interpersonal and Communication Skills: Facilitating group discussions on data analysis
Effective communication of data findings to stakeholders
Problem-Solving and Analytical Skills: Identifying trends and patterns in data for decision-making
Organizational and Leadership Skills: Creating school improvement designs based on data analysis
Leading and managing data-driven decision-making processes

courseDescription: This course teaches aspiring school leaders how politics and policy shapes school-based decision making and how school leaders can influence politics and policy processes to improve learning environments for children.  The course focuses contemporary problems that confront school leaders as they work to improve the conditions of learning for their students, faculty, and staff.  To effectively address and solve problems school leaders need to understand the processes of policymaking at various educational levels and to develop the relevant skills of policymaking needed at the school level.  Thus, this course addresses the following three essential principles of educational politics and policy as they apply to school level administrators: political and policy dynamics that influence their work in schools; accurately identify, diagnose, and develop the right solutions to the right problems in order to achieve instructional goals of the school and division; and confront, engage in, and effectively deal with conflict (i.e., politics) emanating from within the school, division, or community in order to achieve school and division learning goals.
Technical and Digital Skills: Utilizing digital tools for policy research
Interpersonal and Communication Skills: Effective communication with stakeholders in the education system
Problem-Solving and Analytical Skills: Identifying root causes of educational challenges
Critical analysis of education policy documents
Organizational and Leadership Skills: Leading change initiatives in educational settings
Building a shared vision for educational improvement

courseDescription: This course serves as an introduction for prospective administrators to the social and political context of the educational environment.  The underlying concept of this course is collaboration.  Today's administrators face a variety of multifaceted challenges in their daily routines.  Therefore, they must recongize the impact of political, socioeconomic situations, community diversity, equity issues, and school community relations on their leadership practices.
Problem-Solving and Analytical Skills: Identifying communication gaps in external relations
Developing strategic plans for crisis situations
Organizational and Leadership Skills: Building and maintaining relationships with stakeholders

courseDescription: This course provides the necessary knowledge to become an integral part of the educational improvement process at the school, division, and state levels.  Students will analyze and relate the significant educational trends of the past 20 years to the political process, analyzing the impact on school planning.  Students will take an active and vocal role in the discourse and debate about educational policy and practice.  Emphasis will be placed on analyzing the context and implementing planning systems to develop mission, goals and programs that result in educational improvement.
Interpersonal and Communication Skills: Taking an active and vocal role in educational policy discourse
Problem-Solving and Analytical Skills: Analyzing the impact of educational trends on school planning
Organizational and Leadership Skills: Leading educational improvement processes at school, division, and state levels

courseTitle: Leadership for Equity and Inclusive Education
courseDescription: This course focuses on the theories and practices that help educational leaders ensure that students with special needs receive an equitable and inclusive education.   Emphasis is on perspectives of difference versus deviance, historical foundations of specialized programs, current social and legal contexts that influence programming, questions of social justice, and possibilities for the inclusion of all students.  While this course addresses the needs of all students, concentration is on individuals with disabilities and the laws that safeguard their rights.
Technical and Digital Skills: Understanding of special education laws and regulations
Adapting curriculum for students with disabilities
Interpersonal and Communication Skills: Effective communication with students, parents, and staff regarding special needs
Collaborating with stakeholders to create inclusive environments
Problem-Solving and Analytical Skills: Identifying barriers to inclusive education and proposing solutions
Analyzing data to track progress of students with special needs
Organizational and Leadership Skills: Developing and implementing inclusive education policies
Leading a team to support students with disabilities

courseTitle: Policy and Politics in Educational Leadership
courseDescription: This course focuses on the theories and practices needed to build relationships and support from the state political process, the local community, businesses, and media.  Emphasis will be placed on the use of influence, and its impact on relationships, policies, and programs.  Focus is placed on developing a shared vision to bring schools and communities together as partners in improving student learning.  Two-way communication mechanisms for school improvement using political influence and power are examined.
Technical and Digital Skills: Use of influence and power in policy-making
Interpersonal and Communication Skills: Two-way communication mechanisms for school improvement
Developing a shared vision for school-community partnership
Problem-Solving and Analytical Skills: Analyzing the impact of influence on policies
Organizational and Leadership Skills: Managing relationships with state political processes and local community

courseDescription: This course exposes students to the essential elements of instructional leadership.  Central to the skills and knowledge necessary to be an effective instructional leader are a deep understanding of the learning sciences that inform us about the essence of effective teaching.  Effective instructional leaders have a solid basis for assessing and promoting high quality instruction, giving them the tools to proactively build a school's organizational capacity of sustained growth in student achievement.  Students will engage in reading, reflection, dialog, writing, problem solving and field-work, designed to build an understanding of how these topics are intrinsically tied to supporting teachers in their classrooms through facilitating better understandings of standards and accountability, effective lesson planning and curriculum development, assessment and grading, classroom management and discipline.
Problem-Solving and Analytical Skills: Identifying areas for improvement in teaching practices
Organizational and Leadership Skills: Building organizational capacity for growth in student achievement
Supporting teachers through effective lesson planning

courseDescription: This course develops student's skills, knowledge and dispositions in the area of instructional leadership.  Students will explore how effective instructional leaders can use their integrated knowledge of quality instruction and the core principles of learning to set the mission and vision for the school, facilitate school improvement planning and professional development and finally how instructional supervision is used to integrate these activities and support the growth of individual teachers as well as building organizational capacity.  Effective instructional leaders have a solid basis for assessing and promoting high quality instruction, giving them the tools to proactively build a school's organizational capacity for sustained growth in student achievement.  Students will engage in reading, reflection, dialog, writing, problem solving and field-work, designed to help them build an integrated understanding of those leadership practices that help support teacher instructional growth and those that build organizational capacity for sustained improvement.
Interpersonal and Communication Skills: Building relationships with staff and stakeholders
Organizational and Leadership Skills: Supervising and supporting teachers' instructional growth
Building organizational capacity for sustained improvement

courseDescription: This course addresses the design, development, implementation, and alignment of public education accountability systems at the federal, state, and local levels.  Particular attention is given to how the design and implementation of accountability systems affects educational equity and school reform efforts.
Problem-Solving and Analytical Skills: Identification of equity issues in education data

courseTitle: Organizational Theory and Behavior in Education
courseDescription: This course includes the psychology of organizational behaviors, theories of managing people, individual and organizational learning, individual motivation and organizational behavior, interpersonal communications and perceptions, group dynamics, problem management, managing multigroup work, managing diversity, leadership and organizational culture, leadership and decision making, the effective exercise of power and influence, supervision and employee development, organizational analysis, and managing change.
Interpersonal and Communication Skills: Effective exercise of power and influence

courseDescription: This course examines how public schools are financed, including an analysis of the sources of revenues, the distribution of revenue, and the budgeting and expenditure of revenue.  Special emphasis will be placed on the Virginia funding formula, education as an investment in human capital, and how funding relates to student achievement.  Students will learn the fiscal management skills and understandings necessary to manage the finances of a school or school system, including the study of system and school procedures related to budget planning, budget management, internal school account management, inventory control, and purchasing procedures.
Interpersonal and Communication Skills: Collaboration with school staff for budgeting decisions

courseDescription: This course is an introduction to law, particularly with respect to federal and state statutes and court decisions dealing with the public schools.  The topics span a wide spectrum of law-related concerns.  The study of law is intended to be practical by providing the legal understanding necessary for a school administrator to negotiate his or her way through the maze of difficult legal and ethical matters commonly faced each day.
Technical and Digital Skills: Understanding of federal and state statutes
Knowledge of court decisions related to public schools
Interpersonal and Communication Skills: Negotiation skills for legal and ethical matters
Effective communication with stakeholders in education
Problem-Solving and Analytical Skills: Critical analysis of legal issues in education
Organizational and Leadership Skills: Strategic planning for legal compliance in schools
Leading legal and ethical initiatives in education

courseDescription: Course is designed to provide field experiences that will prepare students to serve as instructional and curriculum leadership in K-12 environments.  Student must 1) produce a portfolio with required artifacts; 2) prepare a 10-12 page reflective paper according to identified guidelines and 3) complete internship evaluation with mentor and college supervisor at least three times during the term.  Each internship course will require students to complete a minimum of 160 hours.
Problem-Solving and Analytical Skills: Identifying areas for growth in instructional practices

courseDescription: The course covers the theoretical framework of strategic, operational, cooperative and future planning in education, leading to the development of a cyclic planning process which includes the appropriate tasks, steps and skills to effect administrative and policy change.

This course examines social justice issues related to the financial, political, and operational aspects of America's public schools.  The politics of current legislation, court cases, finances, and operations of the school system are included.
Interpersonal and Communication Skills: Collaboration with stakeholders in school system

courseDescription: In this course, students study and engage in dialogue related to the critical role of education in a democratic society in a rapidly changing and increasingly complex world.  Through a focused discussion of theories and concepts such as democratic schools, social justice, critical theory and power, feminism, critical race theory, and difference/normalization, students come to understand the possible roles education can play in society and their need to continuously reflect on their own vision for leadership in public schools.
Technical and Digital Skills: Digital literacy for social justice advocacy
Interpersonal and Communication Skills: Facilitating dialogue on social justice issues
Problem-Solving and Analytical Skills: Analyzing power dynamics in educational settings
Identifying systemic barriers to social justice
Organizational and Leadership Skills: Advocating for equity in educational policies

courseDescription: In this course, participants examine what is currently known and explore what needs to be known about pedagogy in a context of school renewal.  The foundational perspective for the course is social justice in which course participants seek ways to transform teaching/instruction so that all schools work for all students particularly those students who historically have been disenfranchised from receiving an equitable education.
Interpersonal and Communication Skills: Facilitating discussions on social justice in education
Problem-Solving and Analytical Skills: Identifying and addressing disparities in educational outcomes
Organizational and Leadership Skills: Transforming teaching practices for all students

courseTitle: Field Research in School Administration and Supervision
courseDescription: Field study approach to problems related to school administration and supervision.
Interpersonal and Communication Skills: Effective communication of research findings to diverse audiences
Problem-Solving and Analytical Skills: Identifying root causes of administrative issues
Developing solutions based on data analysis
Organizational and Leadership Skills: Leading research teams in the field

courseDescription: This course examines social justice issues related to the curriculum leadership aspect of America's public schools and abroad.  This course is designed to provide advanced understanding of the curriculum development process through conception, implementation, and evaluation with a particular focus on multiculturalism.  Theoretical and philosophical bases of curriculum development are addressed as well as current trends including brain-based learning, multiculturalism, globalization, organizational thinking and the strategic change process.

This course is a survey of current issues in education, as well as the political, financial, and social issues affecting education leadership.  The course will explore relationships between current issues, historical perspectives, philosophical theories, and sociologic influences.  The exploration of contemporary issues related to equity and achievement will serve as a critical component of the class.
Interpersonal and Communication Skills: Collaborating with diverse stakeholders in education
Presenting findings on contemporary issues in education
Facilitating group discussions on educational equity
Problem-Solving and Analytical Skills: Analyzing data on educational achievement gaps
Identifying solutions for improving educational equity
Evaluating the impact of social issues on educational outcomes
Organizational and Leadership Skills: Leading discussions on education policy changes
Creating action plans for addressing contemporary educational challenges
Managing projects related to educational reform

courseDescription: Study of selected topics in educational leadership.
Technical and Digital Skills: Data analysis for decision-making in education
Interpersonal and Communication Skills: Effective communication with stakeholders in education
Problem-Solving and Analytical Skills: Identifying and addressing challenges in educational leadership
Developing strategies for improving educational outcomes
Organizational and Leadership Skills: Creating a positive organizational culture in education
Leading change initiatives in educational settings

courseDescription: Study of selected topics in urban educational leadership.
Interpersonal and Communication Skills: Effective communication with diverse stakeholders in urban educational settings
Problem-Solving and Analytical Skills: Critical evaluation of urban educational leadership strategies
Organizational and Leadership Skills: Strategic planning for urban educational improvement initiatives

courseDescription: Independent Study, topics in Educational Leadership.
Interpersonal and Communication Skills: Effective communication with stakeholders in education
Problem-Solving and Analytical Skills: Developing strategies for improving educational outcomes

courseDescription: 1-12 credits.

This course is a pass/fail course for master's students in their final semester. It may be taken to fulfill the registration requirement necessary for graduation.  All master's students are required to be registered for at least one graduate credit hour in the semester of their graduation.

This course is a pass/fail course doctoral students may take to maintain active status after successfully passing the candidacy examination.  All doctoral students are required to be registered for at least one graduate credit hour every semester until their graduation.
Technical and Digital Skills: Maintaining active status in doctoral program
Problem-Solving and Analytical Skills: Planning course schedules to meet graduation deadlines
Addressing challenges in the doctoral program
